title: Newcastle United fan saves £50 on rail tickets to Oxford away game - there's just one catch
text:

A football fan was delighted when he managed to save £50 on his rail fare for a last-minute away game - until the tickets arrived. 
Travelling to away games is an expensive business for Newcastle United fans like Jonathan Heywood. 
January’s FA Cup Fourth Round draw and a replay win over Birmingham City gave supporters little time to organise last Saturday’s trip to Oxford United. 
Early-bird cheaper train tickets were long gone by the time Magpies were booking their 500-mile round jaunt to the Kassam Stadium. 
But where there’s a will, there’s a way - Toon fan Jonathan decided to try out ticket-splitting to save money on his rail fare, the Chronicle Live reported . Jonathan travelled to watch Rafa's men in action (Photo: Serena Taylor) 
Jonathan and his girlfriend managed to save around £50 on their travel by using the Rail Easy fare-splitting website. 
But the couple were issued with a whopping 56 tickets to complete their journey. 
Fare-splitting passengers exploit a legal loophole to buy different tickets for each stage of one journey, even if they are staying on the same train throughout. That's a lot of tickets (Photo: Jonathan Heywood) 
The pair actually missed the match - which Newcastle lost 3-0 - as Jonathan says his girlfriend fell over in the stadium concourse and had to be treated in hospital. 
On Twitter, Jonathan thanked his friend who suggested he try out ticket-splitting. 
He lightheartedly branded the tip as “the worst advice” he had ever received. 
On Twitter, he added: “FIFTY SIX TICKETS ARE YOU HAVING ME ON?” 
But, the Toon supporter says he would use the service again to save money. 
He told Chronicle Live : “Absolutely, I saved hassle by organising the tickets into four envelopes and sitting on two unreserved seats to avoid having to swap seats every stop.” 
In May, rail companies including CrossCountry and Virgin will trial out a new ticketing system which aims to eliminate overpriced fares and the need to fare split. 
The aim is to offer customers the cheapest price available for their journey and make ticket machines less confusing. 
Previous research has found one in 20 passengers have been sold overpriced fares by machines. 
Ticket machines have been found to promote expensive fares and “bury” cheaper ones, according to an investigation by the Telegraph. 
Rail Delivery Group - the body which represents Britain’s 23 operating companies - says the jumped-up fares are due to red tape and a complicated ticketing system which has too many ticket options and is riddled with regulations. Like us on Facebook
